questions.title: Hillary defines the establishment!
argument: Yes, Hillary is definitively a seasoned politician who has been at the center of politics for decades, which is exactly why she’s the best candidate for the job

She’s got the experience: As a former secretary of state, U.S. senator, and first lady, no one is more qualified to be president than Hillary. She’s lived with the complicated global and local issues for decades and understands the nuance necessary to make good decisions. With the uncertain political and economic climate we need someone with a clear head and perspective.

She has the contacts: Both within our government and globally, Clinton knows the players. She knows how they think. She’s shared memories and perspectives. International crisis in the Middle East – she knows who to call and how to talk to them. Bills that need to be passed in Washington? She's worked with them all.
America needs a leader with experience, who’s learned the tough lessons, and knows how to apply restraint and perspective to our complicated times.

questions.title: She's corrupt! Look at all those scandals!
argument: Hillary’s been in the public spotlight for a long time. And she’s been the subject of attacks and campaigns to smear her for that long
Accusation doesn’t equal guilt: Let’s first remember, that an accusation doesn’t equal guilt.
No allegations of corruption have ever stuck. In this world of nasty politics and rumors if anything were as earth-shattering as Fox News claims it would have come to trial and conviction.

Check your sources on the internet: There are a lot of crazy scandals and accusations on the internet (Clinton was mean to a dog once, she stole White House furniture, etc etc etc). Please, check your sources, don’t rely on hearsay or gossip.

John Oliver just did a great piece on her scandals as well:

Here's a really good in-depth analysis on investigations into Hillary:

questions.title: Those emails though...
argument: Yes, this is unfortunate. Hillary messed up by having the server in the first place and didn’t handle the whole investigation as well as she could have.

Now, let’s ask ourselves, so what? Big picture, what does this email thing mean?  With everything she has going for her and everything her opponent doesn’t, should we really care?  Here’s the 3 main questions this all distills down to:

Was it criminal: No. The FBI investigation concluded that they do not believe Clinton or her aids deliberately deleted or withheld emails. They also concluded that she did not intentionally or willfully mishandle classified information. Their extensive investigation concluded she acted recklessly but that there would be no charges. And they did not go easy on her or take this investigation lightly.
Did it cause any harm to our country? No. There is no proof, formal charge, or specific allegation – only speculation – that foreign governments could have accessed her emails.

Does it mean we can’t trust her? Is this covering up something bigger? Probably not. Any massive scandal she could be covering up in a deleted email would likely have come out elsewhere. Remember emails are two-way communications – they’re sent from someone to someone. Emails can be forwarded. If there were a huge scandal lurking in her correspondence it would be possible to trace it based on who it was sent to/from.

The F.B.I. found neither, and as a result, he said, “our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case.”
Classification of emails:

questions.title: And she’s owned by Wallstreet!
argument: There’s a lot of attention on Hillary’s Wall Street speeches. Yes, she likely said some corporate platitudes she regrets. But let’s look into this a level deeper:

She should have been talking to and should keep talking to Wall Street: As a Senator from NY, Wall Street was a major constituent. The NY Stock Exchange and NASDEQ are the 1st and 2nd largest stock exchanges in the world. Financial services account for more than 35 percent of the New York City’s employment income. Recent labor stats show that almost 500,000 people are employed in finance in NYC. Wall Street contributes wealth to our nation and also contributes to financial problems. Our politicians NEED to talk to them

She’s given a lot of speeches. Clinton has given nearly 100 paid speeches since leaving the State Department and only 8 were Wall Street. Her Wall Street speeches weren’t even her highest paid speeches
She’s actually been pretty hard on Wall Street: As senator, Clinton’s record for Wall Street reform and speaking out against excesses was solid. So is her plan moving forward.
Finally, just because she spoke to Wall Street Execs…doesn’t mean she is owned by them.  By this logic, the American Camping Association and Ebay, who also paid her to speak, own her too.

sources.title: She should be talking to Wall Street. NY government Labor Stats showing that finance is a major industry and big employer
JP Morgan is the 3rd largest employer in all of NY state. It would be irresponsible for her not to talk to them:

questions.title: She’s untrustworthy!
argument: “Truth” is defined as accordance with fact or reality.  Politifact, a Pulitzer prize-winning fact-checking organization analyzes what politicians say and has rated Hillary’s statements throughout the years. They found 72% of her statements truthful (about the same as Bernie Sanders). By comparison, Trump’s statements were 70% false.

The human side: Imagine the deepest, darkest secrets of your family and your sex life were the subject of national debate, talk shows, and satire for years… wouldn’t you keep things a little closer to your chest?  Wouldn’t you want some privacy? Denying being sick is something we all do

It’s fair to expect more transparency. But it’s a double standard to insist that she has some higher level of purity or truth than any other politician. Are you really being fair by saying she’s untrustworthy?

questions.title: She’s power hungry!
questions.argument: Yes! She’s running for President of The United States, the most powerful position in the world! Anyone running for public office wants power.

sources.title: There’s a good chance there’s some underlying sexism in this statement

questions.title: Look what she did in Benghazi!
argument: What happened in Benghazi was a tragedy and it’s good that Congress is trying to learn the truth about what happened to make sure the mistakes that were made don’t happen again.  What is wrong though is how this has been politicized and used as a witch hunt against Hillary.  In the months of investigation nothing has surfaced indicating her responsibility for the deaths of the American Ambassador and 3 others.

Members of Congress accuse Hillary of not responding to emails asking for more resources for the Embassy that were addressed to her… as we saw in her email scandal she received thousands of emails and cables emails addressed to her from the approximately 307 US embassies around the world. She cannot be expected to personally oversee all of those details… that’s what delegation is for.
Prior to Benghazi, were there 13 attacks on embassies and 66 deaths under President George W. Bush – where is the congressional committee for these attacks?

In 1998 224 people were killed in a bombing at the US embassy in Nairobi and another (that also injured 4,000). Another bombing at the embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, on the same day killed 11 and injured 85.  There was no Congressional Committee
Benghazi was a tragedy that has been over politicized… but it reflects nothing of her leadership.

questions.title: She voted for Iraq!
argument: Iraq is not on Hillary and saying that is forgetting 8 years of Bush
Iraq is on Bush and Cheney and Rumsfeld and Wolfowitz and a whole slew of others who misled the American people, Congress, and the world.

Hillary was one of 77 Senators who voted for the Iraq War resolution (48 Republicans, 29 Democrats). Hillary voted based on the evidence the Bush administration presented. The fact that it was wrong is on them.
